reviewText:
Horribly cheap, Plants vs Zombie-like lane game, its a decent past time game but with hundreds of free flash games out there just like this, the lack of depth and progression system, mixed with the fact that they wasted the 40k license on this games makes me feel disgusting that they did this instead of giving the license out to a studio that actually wants to make a game.

I would imagine myself playing this on a pad or smart phone, if only to get more Dark Angels story but honestly, don't get this, save your money and either buy models, a 40k novel or anything but this. This is by far the worst 40k video game. And as a Dark Angels player this makes me sad as hell, to see them dishonor their own game like this.

When I heard Lane-strategy I thought it was going to be a dota-clone and that actually would have been this, but this game does provide decent voice acting, though they didn't bother to voice act the majority of the dialgoe that's in plain text, the game feel like a Facebook game and its not worth the price their asking for, had this been anything else than 40k, I would have been surprised, but Games Workshop at its finest, is yet again trying to squeeze money out a rock.

reviewText:
http://youtu.be/EYpBwld_a7A

Warhammer 40k Storm of Vengeance is a lane defence strategy game developed by Eutechnyx. Eutechnyx themselves were originally founded in 1987 and their previous titles include The Fast & the Furious: Tokyo Drift, Big Mutha Truckers, NASCAR and did I mention Ride to Hell: Retribution.

The general premise of each battle is simple. Send units to destroy the buildings on the enemies side. Once you have destroyed the buildings you capture the lane. To win a battle capture 3 lanes while making sure the enemy doesn't destroy yours. Each unit and building costs redemption points to produce. Buildings like communication relays build up your redemption points over time. So the idea is to have some redemption production buildings and some unit producing buildings at any one time. There is also the resolve resource, through the skill tree you can unlock special units which cost resolve to field. Resolve is accumulated by turning one of the unit production building into a resolve production building, which halts unit production. While the game may claim to have strategy in reality there’s little to be had, once you grasp the mechanics and limited upgrade system, you can easily win battles without having to put any kind of concentration in what so ever.

In between battles there is a progression system where by you can unlock new units, upgrades and special abilites that use the redemption resource. The progression system is very simplistic and there is no real meat to get your teeth into here, its a very straight forward system that offers little to be excited at. You end up playing the game on fast speed because there's no real reason to watch everything at normal speed, I don't want to see the same battlefield background and same kill animation over and over.

The major issue I have with Storm of Vengeance is that it is lazy and not just lazy, it's lazy to the extreme. Storm of Vengeance's mechanics are an exact and I mean exact replica of Eutechnyx's previous mobile title ninja cats versus samurai dogs. The only major difference between the two titles is that storm of vengeance has slapped some 3D models in there and covered itself with a Warhammer 40k skin.

Storm of Vengeance's story follows the events of the Dark Angels defence of Piscina IV against the green skin tide of the orks. While the story is interesting and is in cannon, it again feels lazy with no effort to make it even slightly entertaining, I mean hell, you didn't build the mechanics from the ground up so why not put in some effort into voice acting or something to make it enjoyable, it just looks and feels poorly executed.

Just because you slap a 40k skin on something doesn't make it codex astartes material. The game lacks any resemblance to a real Warhammer 40k experience and because of this it feels like a blatant licensed cash in. This game could literally be anything, you could place any franchise skin over this game and it would be the exact same.

Now putting the repetitive mechanics and lack of actual strategy aside for one moment, there was also a wee bit of controversy that needs to be discussed. When Storm of Vengeance originally hit steam, I like many thought it was the actual release. Then under closer inspection, the title had beta written at the end. Oh, so it's an early access game I thought, nope. So wait you ask, your saying they just released on steam with beta tagged on the end of the title? Yes pretty much, I couldn't believe it. The first thing I couldn't believe is that Steam allowed that to even happen, if a game is not complete it goes through the early access program, full stop. Second, you cannot just throw beta on your title and expect that to save you from criticism. Even worse the developers at first said there wasn't time for the game to go under early access, which as we know is now utter bull ♥♥♥♥ since since a backlash they quickly went to hide under early access. That kind of thing is seriously dodgy stuff, as a developer you should know not to pull that kind of ♥♥♥♥ and you should definitely know that if you do, your going to get called out on it.

Anyway back to the actual game. The thing is with Storm of Vengeance is that its fun for about 10 minutes and then after that it's not. It's a shallow mobile title and that is exactly what is should only be, a mobile title. This is not a core gaming experience that fans of the franchise want, what it is however is something to pass the time on the train to work. Look at it this way On Steam Storm of Vengeance costs £6.99. On iOS and Android it costs £2.99, for the exact same game. So if you want to get it, but it on your mobile device and use it as a superficial time passer.

reviewText: I actually managed to play through this game, in its Beta state, simply to say that I did it. It managed to be quite dull, unimaginative, and repetitive as each mission required you to place buildings which will build units that you then assign to lanes to attack enemy structures. This wouldn't be so bad if the game weren't so ponderously paced and there were more than 2 useful units. I didn't use assault marines at all throughout the campaign. Also, a good number of the upgrades for your units are essentially useless, and trying to put more than one upgrade on a marine at a time is tantamount to a death sentence because of how drastically it increases their build times.\n\nMy overall impressions of this game are very poor. I understand that it's still in beta and there will be tweaks, but all in all I don't have any faith that this project will improve enough to make me want to play it again. It's dull, and not even the beloved Warhammer 40k license can change that. If anything, I'm disappointed that it's a 40k game. If it weren't, I probably wouldn't have even given this game the benefit of the doubt and saved myself $10.

reviewText:
I purchased this game on deep discount, expecting some good old Ork slaying in the vein of Plants vs. Zombies. While it never got good, it sure got old, and fast.

- No matter how hard I tried, I could only select Orks as my campaign. Until the game crashed.
- Every level past the first few can be defeated with the same 3-troop, 2-Teef setup, eventually swapping out a Teef building for an armory. There is little to no variety in the levels-though sometimes out of boredom I would attempt to beat them with 3-tower setups or building Trukks.
- Skirmish levels were an interesting concept, with limited troops and options, but only one took more than 2 tries to complete. That one took about 20, because it required both a little luck and impeccable timing. I only completed it out of spite.

Scratches neither the PvZ nor the WH40K itches-and if it can't do that, I don't think this game does anything but bore and frustrate.

reviewText:
Sale Recommendation: -90% Off.

It's a tough break for this Warhammer 40K tug-of-war game. I wanted, so very badly to enjoy this game.  I picked it up because the Dark Angels chapter never received enough love in my eyes.

First the good news: The storyline and written dialogue is spot on. The game offers pretty solid 3D animations, except with noticeable glitches. The fundamentals of the gameplay are actually pretty awesome.

Now for the long-winded But
date:
: There are simply way too many interface bugs which force the player to restart what could have been an otherwise good match. These experiences become more noticeable and frustrating towards the end-game where every move really counts. You hope to sweep down the line of maurauding Orks with a heavy bolter, all of the sudden you are unable to click on your unit. The interface doesn't offer the user any notice of when their unit has been interrupted by an enemy attack, leaving you clicking wildly at buttons which should be greyed out.

The 2D interface felt splotchy and rough, with misaligned text noticeable everywhere on smaller resolutions.
The cross-platform and multiplayer features do not function as advertised, with the multiplayer servers down.

The icing on the cake is when you finish through the entire Dark Angels campaign:
The game's singular achievement does not trigger, even if you 100% every bonus mission.
Don't pick this one up any time soon, unless it receives some serious update love.

reviewText:
Whilst I can understand that alot of people are disappointed with the game for what it is, you get what you pay for - I would personally rather pay a full 40-50 pounds for a Top A-Title from the Games Workshop IP.

If you only pay around a fiver, you need to have certain expectations, sadly even despite expecting it to be a very very basic game, it was incredibly simple, extremely repetitive and you could determine whether you were going to complete the level within the first minute.

Having been through and completed all the campaign missions to 100%, there has yet to been an actual ending to the game. I also seem to have not been granted the single lone achievement for completion. All in all, it's not a very good game but it makes me appreciate the other games released under the IP, such as DOW and Space Marine.

It seems that Games Workshop is slowly becoming a cash cow, rather than the company with strict standards to protect it's trademark and intellectual property that we are used to.

reviewText:
This game is bad in parts but I had some fun playing it.

Typical lane defense game AKA that genre born from 'Plants vs Zombies'.
This game is bad, which is a harsh thing to say since its jut a reskin of another game, Samurai Dogs vs Ninja Cats which in itself is an okay game, so what went wrong?

These lane games thrive on 2 things. A challenging AI and good multiplayer support. If they don't get those right the game is dead on arrival, guess what this game is?

Its a bad game for sure but its just bad. Its not terrible its just a blatant cash grab with no effort made and no soul to the game. Samurai Dogs is actually fun to play at times but is sadly mobile only.

I think overall this game got a bad reputation and a mass denounciation train started. The scores are exaggeratedly low and calling this game crap seems to be the norm, similar to how E.T. was a terrible" game
date:
when it was really just dull and boring. At least effort was made for E.T. whereas this reskin feels lazy at numerous points and parts.

If you have a mobile gaming platform then check out Samurai Dogs vs Ninja Cats. This game even on sale seems to seldom work correctly and match making is broken and has been abandoned by the devs so its a single player game for all intents and purposes.
It doesn't live up to the hype about how "terrible" it is which is actually disappointing since that makes it even more forgetable.

Join Grumpy reviews for all your gaming needs
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/grumpyreviews"

reviewText:
This is a terrible, terrible game. Lane strategy with cards? As a lover of Warhammer 40,000, I figured I would give this a try. However... I regretted my purchase immensely. No card game mechanics, no strategy to speak of whatsoever, this is immensely disappointing. The gameplay is stale and boring, with the creation of buildings leading to the deployment of units in up to 5 lanes. There are some minor variations, but nothing really worthwhile. A lot of this is also actually RNG-based instead of revolving around any worthwhile strategy.

The lack of depth and progression is only matched by the fact that the skills and abilities are nothing spectacular either. The graphics are pretty poor, but considering the rest of the game, especially with the buggy interface... just save yourself the trouble, and keep your money in your wallet for something worthwhile. The voice acting, what little there is, is reasonable, but the rest of the audio is mediocre at best.

I did not expect a Games Workshop licensed game to be this poor. Learn from my mistakes, and avoid this game. My favourite part was when I uninstalled.

reviewText:
While typing this the one word that kept coming to mind was ... dull.

If you have $9.99 to spare and will do anything to have a Warhammer title no matter the quality then, uhm, ... ok i guess so.

WH 40k:SoV is a repetitive un-inspired Warhammer themed game and at best an average lane defence game.  It has bland sound effects, and the graphics are dull with neither using to any potential the richness that could be put in considering the source material around which it is themed. Ignoring the WH 40K theming the graphics are still, especially the backgrounds , dull and the sounds bland.

Over all the game is not as much fun as some free to download TD or LD games.  The usage of Warhammer 40K imagery is irrelevant as it ignores the mythos created around Space Marines and treats them as literal cannon fodder (or like Imperial Guardsmen for the WH 40k fan) to be wasted in useless lane combat.

I would say at best i would give this game 4/10 and that is because I am a fan of Warhammer 40k and so just skinning it to represent the noble and glorious Adeptus Astartes gives it a few points.

I must add an addendum now though.  After a few more hours of play I have to say that it is mildly addictive and will eat up some time initially.  I reckon I may play an hour once every month or two till i bore of it for a bit again.

reviewText:
''I Fink i 'ave wot dem Umies kall ''buyers remorse'' or Sumfin.. - Warboss Grizrak.''

I'll admit it, i purchased this game as soon as i saw it was 40k title if nothing else then to support the franchise (and orks are amazingly fun to play as in just about any game there in) but i really wish i put more time into researching this and if id known what i do now id of certainly spend my money on somthing more worthwhile.

Aside from the game being cheaper on the iOS store the game was developed by Eutechnyx, if the name sounds familiar take a look at a game called Ride to Hell Retribution, oh my are we already off to a good start! granted this game is nowhere near the atocity for the formentioned but WH40:SoV does maintain the companies reputation of rather lackluster titles.

Ingame 'cutscenes' if they can be called that use still images taken from the tabletop rulebooks rather then having an art team create origional illustrations and even go as far as to use sculpted parts from the table top game models as icons for the game (The Ork upgrades are a good example of this), Audio is present for the units if rather repetitive (much like its gameplay) and are also absent from those still image cutscenes.. the game as a whole can best be discribed as 'lazy' and 'found wanting'.

You'd think with how rabid Games Workshop have been over the years to guard its intellectual property like a overly bloated and aggressive dog guards is favorate chewtoy they would take better care of who they allow to use there licence but apparently having there asses handed to them by the consumer losing 24% of there shares value this year alone has made GW all the more desperate, if this gets any more dare we may find them Selling off a tied and bound Matt Ward off to the lynch mob with the biggest wallet!

Also why the hell would they have a company thats more renound for there racing games develop a Lane strategy game? there clearly out of there element, personally Id of made them work on and complete a racing game based on your old GorkaMorka game! the one that was going to be launched on the dreamcast but died with the system, then you'd actually have a decent game thats not only a gritty and violent version of Mario Kart but also allow Eutechnyx redeem themselves for such a shoddy track record.

The only way they could really make this any worse was if they added micro transactions so you can unlock new units and paintjobs for alternative space marine chapters and Ork Klans... Oh, nevermind, it's called DLC now... DLC for a game thats just been released can could use all the help it can get, and its behind a paywall with a game thats already overpriced for entry simply for being a PC port.

Shame on Games Workshop for having little care of there franchise to green light this, Shame on Eutechnyx just in general and shame on me for buying this game before doing the research or waiting for more reviews, dont make the same mistake i did, you want a good warhammer game? Dark Omen, Chaos Gate, The Dawn of War series, Hell even Fire Warrior, you have so many options and better purchases to get your 40k fix, just not this.

reviewText:
Seemed okay at first. $10 was a bit steep. I found out afterwards that this is basically a reskin. To be honest, I'm a huge Dark Angel fan, and I've played them faithfully since the end of 2nd Edition. That's the main reason I tried the game out. Aside from being massively repetative with only the simple strategy of unit rushing a basic, unupgraded marine, I felt the game had some promise. It needed a major mechanic tweak to make upgrades and special abilities worth while. As it is, you have to choose to build or to use global abilities. Since global abilities are supposed to augment your main units, you end up massively handicapped if you bother with them.

Still, with some updates and more units, I felt the game would have some life and value in it. Then, they released paid DLC. This  buried any hope the game had. You can get a decent mobile game for $2.99. This is a mobile game on your computer for $16, and it still isn't complete. Why would I do that when FTL and Starbound are cheaper with a million times more content? This has one map and 100% existing artwork .The only thing unique is the very few 3d models in the game. And of them, almost all are on the Dark Angel side. Orks get generic boxes for buildings (you'd think they would get battlewagons, death rollas, etc). It also doesn't follow lore. Dark Angels don't have Stormravens.

Bottom line - Stay away. They're aiming to nickel and dime you with an incomplete game.

reviewText:
I'm not sure why this game has got so many negative reviews as it is a decent and well made casual strategy game.  The problem may be this being a 40K title the expectations are for something grand, complex and epic like the Dawn of War series but this is a simple to play Plants vs Zombies tower defense of game which has been ported to Steam from the mobile devices.

Though it is a casual and lane based game it does provide a decent amount of enjoyable challenge and there are plenty of upgrades, units and sprecial abilities to utilize these can be upgraded as the game progresses. There is a good story between each of the battles that tell the story of an Ork invasion of an Imperial colony world that the Dark Angel chapter of Space Marines and an Imperial Guard regiment (Imperial Guard being available as DLC they are well worth getting for the entirely new story, units and gameplay style), the story is well written and true to the 40K lore.

The graphics are nicely crafted and do a good job of portraying the grim wartorn 40K universe and the units are well animated, everything looks the way it should given the limits of a casual  2D game of this type.  The music is suitably operatic and over the top epic in style much like a DoW game and the sound effects are authentic and really add to the atmosphere of an intense battle taking place as well particularly the voice samples of the units, there is nothing better in a 40K game than seeing a Space Marine swaggering onto the battlefield shouting Xenos scum!" or "Greenskins!" at a bunch of orks before blasting them with his bolter
date: that's really what 40K is all about at the end of the day and that's what this game delivers succesfully.\n\nSo everything you would want from a 40K game is here in essence providing you understand that this is a casual game you can play for 10 minutes now and again and you're not looking for the full DoW experience."

reviewText: Note: This review was written around a week into the Beta launch of the game.\n\nThis is a small, fun game, with matches running at a pace perfect for a quick interlude for people with a busy schedule. It's good for when you're too tired to play a serious game for serious gamers" but still feel like venting off some steam. Personally
date: I was a bit on the fence about whether or not the price was justified
recommended: and at launch there was certainly a reason for outrage. Presently my doubts have been assuaged
hoursPlayed: as the beta has progressed and features were added. I don't know the story behind why this game was originally launched as a complete game with a Beta tag in the title art
voteText: but ultimately the team conceded to the demands in the forums that it be marketed as an Early Launch.\n\nWhat I do know is that the dev team has waddled through torrents of hate and vitriol in the Steam forums searching for feedback and answering back constructively to a community that by and large has shown them nothing but contempt. I don't know if they're the same individuals responsible for Ride to Hell: Retribution
helpfulPercent: a fact which people have fallaciously used to damn the game by association. I've seen them take a serious approach to improving the game they've made based on user feedback that isn't pasting a certain video by a certain celebrity or slaughtering the game based on some imaginary quality barrier set by "the community" for video games based on the 40K IP. Personally
votesHelpful: I think that speaks for itself regarding their commitment.\n\nThe reason I'm recommending the game is as a way of vouching for the team's continuous dedication to the betterment of this project. Note that at this point
votesTotal: there will be bugs of varying degrees of severity
votesFunny: and you have the Early Access joy of reporting them and assisting in their squashing. This is obviously not something everyone will enjoy. Likewise
commentsCount: if you absolutely loathe the concept of a lane defence game you will probably not enjoy this. But if you're at least partially willing to give it a try regardless of the vocal detractors
column16: I assure you this game is worth the benefit of the doubt. It certainly won't demand a lot of your time."

reviewText: This game is exactly what it says in the tin. It's currently a small lane strategy game, but that doesn't mean it shouldn't be brought. It has a decent selection of skill tree development and, whilst I don't take much of an interest in the more complex lane strategy games, I did find Warhammer 40,000: storm of vengeance to be a nice game for a reasonable price. I think that the large number of negative comments for this game have been awefully misleading, as it is still in development but I could easily see this game being released already so I will be looking forward to seeing what else Eutechnyx add to it. Overall, it's not a typical Warhammer 40k game, it's not big and flashy with many different factions but I do believe it to be a good, quick little game that isn't too much of a difficulty to learn or play.

reviewText:
First and foremost its a phone game and second it is in beta says so in the title even though i won't give to much leniency because steam has an area of early access to release for sale beta and alpha games.  as a phone games it is pretty fun, it is however a light casual time waster of a game in its mechanics, namely pick a spot summon either a troop making thing or money making thing mechanic.  there are no pay walls or major timers that have been occuring more and more often in phone games. this game doesn't do anything new that we havn't seen before, but what it does do is still enjoyable.

as to the 40k part well thats another story.  there is a mild amount of a story going on in this game of orks attacking a planet and having to fend them off as dark angels, but the main reason to play this would be as a time waster; once again this is a PHONE game.  Once this game is released from beta and completed I think that this will be a fun game to play when you either don't have the time or patience to sit down for some hardcore gaming, or when your at work doing a crappy job you hate.  As to the 40k universe being involved I have yet to see anything that would really make this feel like a Warhammer 40k game.  Most of the gritty and dark aspects of the 40k universe are toned down to make the game more viable mass market.  this style of gameplay could be done with anything and it would not be any different which means to me that the universe is simply being used to sell copies to GW fans like me.

Final thoughts is that if you are lookin for a casual time waster phone game and willing to beta test an unfinished product it is worth your time. however if you are looking for the next big game in the 40k universe, or something with that same level of story and gameplay as past warhammer 40k games you will be disappointed.  Once again this is a phone game in beta even though the devs should have put it in early access area.

reviewText:
Storm of Vengeance is a Plants vs. Zombies re-themed 40K clone

UPD : After playing more hours of the game, my original glowing positive 8/10 review (recommending the product) had to be re-edited.

It's worst then Plants vs. Zombies, too many bugs, the art, sound, game play and theme would make it much superior, BUT there is just too many bugs, too often, especially in the second half of the game, when all units are unlocked.

I cannot recommend this as it stand, major patching required.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
In many ways this is a fun and engaging game, but it has some fatal flaws.

First and foremost, it does not always register your clicks. In some games this would just be an annoyance but in this game it's much more.  A number of actions in this game take multiple focused clicks to work and they are in real time. For instance, to throw a grenade you first have to click on the unit with the grenade and then click on where to throw it. The problem is that when you click to throw it if you click on an invalid area (and for abilities that focus on another unit 99% of the screen is an invalid area) then the original action is unselected and you have to start this multi-part action all over. Add to this how often you click right on another unit and it doesn’t register and this is hugely frustrating. Mind you, this is real time so missing an action can easily cost you a round.

The other large annoyances are have no indication of when a special action is available, meaning you have to constantly flip to another screen to check it, and that units you control are notably weaker than the same units when the AI controls them (which says to me they couldn’t get the AI to work well so they weakened the player’s units to compensate).
This game has real potential and I kept going back to it to see if I could find a way to make it work. Ultimately, however, it became so frustrating I removed it completely from my computer.

reviewText:
This game kind of sucks. Let me say a few good things mixed in with a lot of bad:

the gameplay isn't special, but it's fun for a bit. The game claims to be a card game, but it's not at all.. Just ignore that. The whole game is a lane-train where you march your guys down lanes through enemy guys until you destroy the building at the other end and claim that lane. Do this three times and you win. There's a small modicum of strategy to this, but with the amount of RNG in this, your best strategy is just ramming most of your troops down a lane until it breaks. Rarely will you do anything other than this. The game's sound effects, poor graphics with a number of clipping and hitbox issues detract from the experience. attack animations are totally out of sync with projectiles and sound effects. On top of all this, the story could be compelling, but it is unengaging and boring because of how it is presented. It's just a number of back and forth conversations presented in crude textboxes with no sound or visuals. The campaign battle map is useless, do nothing for the game. It attempts to at least show you where the fight is taking place in relation to other locations, but with zero indicators or landmarks on the map, you will have no idea where anything is. In combat, there are a number of glitches that are especially annoying, such as how the interface loses functionality over time and buttons stop working regularly. There will be times when you will be trying to redeploy a dark angel on the brink of death and he will die because you're furiously clicking on his body, but the redeploy won't go off.

DO NOT BUY ANY DLC. NONE OF IT'S WORTH IT. THE SKINS LOOK TERRIBLE AND THE NEW UNITS SERVE NO PURPOSE AND SUPPORTS A PAY-TO-WIN THEME (DISPITE THEM BEING USELESS). THE IMPERIAL GUARD ARE TERRIBLY DESIGNED AND GIMPED, WITH MANY FUNCTIONS STRAIGHT UP NOT WORKING.

As for the two core races.... eh. The Dark Angels are fun to play, with a handful of different styles and focuses to try if you are interested. They are definately superior to the other two factions. Their abilities and units are very powerful, with enough variety to be ready to respond to anything the other two factions have with speed and effectiveness. The orks are very difficult to play competitively, as since they need a build to make troops and a second build to make upgrades for them, they are unable to make the number of troops they would need to balance the flexibility of the space marines. There's more, but that's all I'm going to bother saying. I had a bit fun with the game, and played it a lot. But, bottom line, it sucks.

total score 3/10
